abstract: The government agreed to provide a fresh capital injection and absorb as much as $98.2 billion in losses.
snippet: The government agreed to provide a fresh capital injection and absorb as much as $98.2 billion in losses.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth D. Lewis gambled on bold acquisitions to build Bank of America into the nation’s largest bank.

headline.main: Bank of America to Receive Additional $20 Billion
headline.print_headline: Bank of America to Receive $20 Billion More

byline.original: By Eric Dash, Louise Story and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: The recent acquisitions made by Bank of America make up the sort of track record that should lead to the quick firing of its chief executive. But he might not be entirely at fault for Merrill Lynch.
snippet: The recent acquisitions made by Bank of America make up the sort of track record that should lead to the quick firing of its chief executive. But he might not be entirely at fault for Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: By rights, Kenneth D. Lewis should lose his job as chief executive of Bank of America for tapping the government for a second round of financial support. His frenzied deal-making in recent years left the bank low on capital and destroyed $140 billion of shareholder value. Shareholders may certainly feel aggrieved that the architect of that strategy is still in the corner office. They may be hoping that the government demands his head in return for handing over more federal aid. They may be disappointed.

byline.original: By ANTONY CURRIE and JOHN FOLEY

headline.main: Dubious Moves Can’t Sink BofA Chief

abstract: Bank of America’s chairman came under fire from investors wanting to know why the bank did not notify them of Merrill’s losses in December.
snippet: Bank of America’s chairman came under fire from investors wanting to know why the bank did not notify them of Merrill’s losses in December.
lead_paragraph: Just months ago, Kenneth D. Lewis was the triumphant hero.

headline.main: For Bank of America, the Pressure Mounts Over Merrill Deal
